taxon_identification.other_info_on_name: [for P. H. G. Moehring, 1710–1791, Danzig naturalist]

bio:treatment.discussion: Members of Moehringia and Petrocoptis (a segregate from Silene, comprising four species in the Pyrenees) are the only Caryophyllaceae with strophioles (eliasomes), spongy seed appendages that attract ants. Foraging ants gather the seeds, eat only the strophiole, and “plant” the seeds in their nests.

We follow J. McNeill (1962) and V. Bittrich (1993) among others in recognizing Moehringia. The appendaged (strophiolate) seed and a chromosome base number of 12 are the chief characters distinguishing Moehringia from Arenaria. Although McNeill noted that this distinction is similar to features used to distinguish subgenera within Arenaria, he retained Moehringia and suggested that, among other evidence, cytological investigation of the North American species of Moehringia and members of Arenaria subg. Leiosperma McNeill (New World, especially Andean South America) would help support such action. Chromosome counts made since 1962 do show x = 12 in North American Moehringia and x = (10) 11 for Arenaria subg. Leiosperma.

key_statement.description: Plants annual (or short-lived perennial?); stems prostrate or ascending, pubsecence in 2 lines; leaves petiolate, petioles 1–4 mm, blade ovate to broadly ovate
Plants perennial, with extensive rhizome systems; stems prostrate or ascending to erect, pubescence ± uniform; leaves sessile or subsessile, petioles 0.1–1 mm, blade mostly lanceolate to elliptic.
Stem pubsecence retrorse; sepals (herbaceous portion) oblong to elliptic, apex mostly rounded or obtuse, 1.7–2.8(–3) mm; petals ca. 2 times as long as sepals
Stem pubescence peglike, spreading; sepals (herbaceous portion) lanceolate, apex acute to acuminate, (2.8–)3–6 mm; petals 3 / 4 –1 1 / 2 times as long as sepals
